Today we're celebrating one of the best creatures around, it's International Beaver Day! Did you know that beaver dams help reduce pollution? It's true, beaver dams restore streams and habitats. Photo taken in Nahanni National Park Reserve. Parks Canada NWT

caption_original: Hoppy Easter!!! While rabbits are a symbol of Easter fun and are totally cute, it's important to keep animals and yourself safe by keeping your distance and never feeding wildlife. caption_original: Jasper National Park has five peaks named after Victoria Cross recipients with connections to Alberta, including Mount Pattison, dedicated to Private John G. Pattison. In 1917, Pattison singlehandedly overtook an enemy machine gun during the Battle of #Vimy Ridge. #Vimy100

caption_original: This day in 1733 marked the first time a lighthouse was lit in what we now call Canada. The Louisbourg Lighthouse that stands today is the third constructed in the very same spot as the original centuries ago. Discover heritage lighthouses across the country: http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/pp-hl How many have you visited? Fortress of Louisbourg National Historic Site Canada Keep Exploring

caption_original: Tomorrow is Auyuittuq's birthday! Well, the anniversary of its creation as a national park. The most accessible of the Nunavut parks, its raw beauty can also be experienced on a spring snowmobile day-trip to the Arctic Circle or summer hike to Ulu Peak. Did you know the Inuktitut word "auyuittuq" means "the land that never melts"? Even so, it's famous for its stunning blooming season in July and early August. Plan your visit: http://ow.ly/2Hcw30aczlb Parks Canada Nunavut

caption_original:
The Blanding‚Äôs turtle is a medium-sized freshwater turtle, which is readily distinguished by its bright yellow throat and chin. They typically live a very long life (80+ years).  
We have taken concrete action at several of our national parks including Kejimkujik National Park in Nova Scotia, and Point Pelee and Georgian Bay Islands National Parks and more recently, in Rouge National Urban Park in Ontario to protect and restore Blanding Turtles and their habitat.  

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

caption_original:
Presentation swords like this one are decorative, and were most often presented as gifts for impressive achievements, to be worn on special occasions. This sword was presented by the Legislature of Upper Canada in 1816 in recognition of Lieutenant-Colonel Francis Battersby's services. He was a British Commander who served during the War of 1812. 

Discover more artefacts under our care by following #OurVaults on @PCarchaeology. https://twitter.com/pcarchaeology

caption_original:
The Fenian Brotherhood was formed in the United States in 1858. They sought independence for Ireland from Britain and the establishment of an Irish Republic. The American Fenians planned a series of raids to seize the transportation network of Canada, in order to force the British to exchange Ireland‚Äôs freedom for possession of Canada. They planned and partly executed raids in Ontario, Quebec, Manitoba and the Maritimes in 1866, 1870 and 1871. This extremely rare example of a Fenian jacket was taken from a Fenian prisoner in Quebec in May of 1870. 

Discover more artefacts under our care by following #OurVaults on @PCarchaeology. https://twitter.com/pcarchaeology

They planned and partly executed raids in Ontario, Quebec, Manitoba and the Maritimes in , and . This extremely rare example of a Fenian jacket was taken from a Fenian prisoner in Quebec in May of . caption_original:
Happy National Wildlife Week! 

The vast majority of whoopers breed in Wood Buffalo National Park, located along the border of Alberta and the Northwest Territories, and they winter only in a small marsh on the coast of Texas.  
We have been working with partners for 50 years to protect their important nesting habitat within Wood Buffalo National Park and to date, our data shows that these recovery efforts are working!

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

SGang Gwaay, located in the exposed southwest corner of Gwaii Haanas - Islands of Beauty, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site that showcases Haida art and way of life. The Haida name means Wailing Island, based on a sound created at certain tides when air is pushed through a hole in a rock on the island.

To celebrate #Canada150, we‚Äôre featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original:
The beluga whale, nicknamed the ‚Äúsea canary‚Äù because of its diverse and frequent vocalisations, is a fascinating species which lives in a complex social structure.  With its white skin, prominent forehead and lack of dorsal fin, it is easily recognizable among marine mammals. The St. Lawrence beluga is a year-round resident of the St. Lawrence River and depends on the Saguenay-St. Lawrence Marine Park to feed and rear its young.  

We are working with the Department of Fisheries and Oceans and others to encourage the recovery of this endangered species by enhancing protection of its critical habitat. Awareness campaigns, patrolling and new regulations have reduced the threats on belugas caused by boat traffic.

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

caption_original:
The Northern Leopard Frog has a very distinctive call that sounds like a door creaking open, followed by a little chuckle sound.  Once the most wide-spread frog in North America, it started to mysteriously disappear from much of southwestern Canada, including Waterton Lakes National Park in Alberta, in the late 1970s. 

We are taking northern leopard frog egg masses from Grasslands National Park, where the frog populations are healthy, and bringing them back to Waterton Lakes.  Our scientists are also working alongside the Calgary Zoological Society to take the search for the missing frogs to the genetic level using an innovative environmental DNA (eDNA) monitoring technique.  

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

We are taking northern leopard frog egg masses from Grasslands National Park, where the frog populations are healthy, and bringing them back to Waterton Lakes. Our scientists are also working alongside the Calgary Zoological Society to take the search for the missing frogs to the genetic level using an innovative environmental DNA (eDNA) monitoring technique. As an active participant in preserving and presenting the country‚Äôs military heritage, we commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Second World War by launching Home Port Heroes. This initiative is a way to honour the sacrifices made by the men and women who served in, and built the cargo ships of the Merchant Navy and highlights the historic connection between merchant vessels and Parks Canada‚Äôs network of treasured places. 

Follow #HomePortHeroes to find out more about the amazing contributions of Canada‚Äôs Merchant Navy during the Second World War. 

http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/culture/historique-historic/mer-port

caption_original: From 1914 to 1918, Fort George and Fort Mississauga National Historic Sites formed Camp Niagara, which served as a military training camp for 14,000 Canadian soldiers. Many of them were sent overseas to serve their country on the battlefields of Europe, including #Vimy Ridge, in 1917. #Vimy100

caption_original:
Ancient Murrelets (or Night Birds in the Haida language) ‚Äì are a handsome black and white seabird of the North Pacific:  the "penguin" of Canada. Ancient Murrelet colonies in Gwaii Haanas are threatened by invasive rats that arrived with the first sailing ships. These birds are a barometer of the health, both of the marine ecosystems and the remote islands on which they breed. 
With the Haida Nation and several Canadian and international partners, we have successfully restored breeding habitat for the Ancient Murrelet on three islands.

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

These birds are a barometer of the health, both of the marine ecosystems and the remote islands on which they breed. caption_original: Lester B. Pearson ‚Äì our country‚Äôs 14th Prime Minister ‚Äì was a world statesman and a proud Canadian. He is someone who left a larger-than-life mark, not only on Canada, but on the global community. His lifetime accomplishments and legacy were recognised today at the National Arts Centre / Centre national des Arts in Ottawa. Two plaques commemorating some of his achievements were unveiled and the former prime minister was honoured as a person of national historic significance.

Explore Canada‚Äôs history at Woodside National Historic Site, in Kitchener, Ontario, the boyhood home of William Lyon Mackenzie King, Canada‚Äôs tenth, and longest-serving Prime Minister. This lovingly preserved Victorian home, filled with King family heirlooms and period reproductions, and set on 11.5 acres of mature forest, is a portal to the Victorian era in Canada.

To celebrate #Canada150, we‚Äôre featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

caption_original:
Private Charles Traveller, 70th (the Surrey) Regiment of Foot painted this self-portrait in La Prairie, in 1841. It is one of the few known paintings by a common soldier of the era. 

Discover more artefacts under our care by following #OurVaults on @PCarchaeology. https://twitter.com/pcarchaeology
